statement:
The *power rule* states that

$${\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^p = px^{p-1}, \quad p \in \mathbb{R}$$

This rule, when combined with the chain rule, product rule, and sum
rule, makes calculating many derivatives far more tractable. This rule
can be derived by repeated application of the product rule. See the .

Repeated use of the above formula gives

$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{d^i}{dx^i}x^k=
\begin{cases}
0&i>k\\
\frac{k!}{(k-i)!}x^{k-i}&i\leq k,
\end{cases}\end{aligned}$$

for $i,k\in\mathbb{Z}$.

Examples {#examples .unnumbered}
--------

$$\begin{aligned}
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^0 & = & \frac{0}{x} = 0 = {\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}1 \\
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^1 & = & 1x^0 = 1 = {\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x \\
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^2 & = & 2x \\
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^3 & = & 3x^2 \\
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}\sqrt{x} & = & {\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}x^{1/2} = \frac{1}{2}x^{-1/2} = \frac{1}{2\sqrt{x}} \\
{\ensuremath{\frac{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}}}}{{\ensuremath{\mathrm{d}x}}}}}2x^e & = & 2ex^{e-1}\end{aligned}$$
